Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: The city newsletter includes a short survey about bus routes open through next week.
Story: The line at my register snakes past the candy racks, and the beeping of scanned items is relentless. I force a smile as the next customer slams her groceries on the belt, her voice sharp with frustration about a coupon that won’t scan. I remind myself to stay calm, to be the friendly cashier everyone expects, even as my own patience thins. My phone buzzes in my apron pocket—a reminder about the city’s bus route survey, open only until tomorrow. As a citizen, I know I should take a few minutes to give feedback; the new routes could affect my commute and my neighbors’. But the store is packed, my break is short, and my manager expects me back on the floor right away. I feel the pressure mounting: the demand to be present and helpful at work, and the responsibility to participate in decisions that shape my city. My heart pounds as I wonder which expectation I’ll have to let down.
